It should be remembered, however, that, in an · ode of Pindar, composed for a religious and patriotic festival, a fine local myth, showing forth ‘the glories of our birth and state‚’ was especially appropriate ; and that moralizing too was, in Pindar's day, as much expected of the poet as fine images and musical rhythms. He was the popular philosopher, the seer who could discern the tendencies of men's actions and could pronounce upon them with due blame or praise.

Horace derived, then, from his Greek models a certain discursiveness in his treatment of a theme. He took from them also an extreme ‘abruptness' of manner, such that it is often difficult to follow the train of his thoughts (see, for instance, 1. 7 or 11. 2 or 111. 4 or lv. 9). This abruptness is due partly to the brevity of his diction and partly to a literary con· vention. As the poet Gray wrote to his friend Mason, ‘extreme conciseness of expression, yet pure, perspicuous and musical, is one of the great beauties of lyric poetry.’ And the reason is obvious. In short lines, with a marked rhythmical beat, almost every word becomes emphatic and must deserve to be emphatic. This conciseness necessarily leads to abruptness of thought, for the conjunctions and brief explanatory phrases which, in a sreer style of composition, serve to mark the connexion of ideas, are excluded from lyrics by their unemphatic character. It is a convention also, between poets and their audience, that lyrics, however elaborate, should profess to be written on the inspira- tion of the moment, and should therefore seem to be hurried, unpremeditated, unmethodical. They are spoilt if they become argumentative.
